newsitem.title: CHINA: China interbank market volume up in April.
newsitem.headline: China interbank market volume up in April.

text.p: Turnover on China's interbank market based in Shanghai was 43.956 billion yuan in April, up sharply on the same month last year but down on March, official figures released on Thursday indicated.
The Shanghai Securities News said total trades on both the first and second tier markets averaged 1.998 billion yuan per trading day, 464 million yuan down on the average for March.
Trading on the market in April last year totalled 35.385 billion yuan.

The interbank market, created in January 1996, is a means by which major banks and other institutions can swap yuan funds of different durations from one to 120 days. Seven contracts are currently offered.
The government has vowed to expand volume on the market dramatically this year.

The market now consists of 20 major state bank head offices and 35 short-term financing centres as its first tier members, with hundreds of banks and other institutions operating as second tier members trading through the centres.
Foreign banks have been allowed to trade on the interbank market for the first time over the past month.
